modules.name: Data.Char
modules.comments: A type and functions for single characters.

declarations.comments: Returns the numeric Unicode value of the character.
declarations.title: toCharCode

declarations.comments: Constructs a character from the given Unicode numeric value.
declarations.title: fromCharCode

declarations.comments: Generates a character of the Unicode basic multilingual plane.
declarations.title: genUnicodeChar

declarations.comments: Generates a character in the ASCII character set, excluding control codes.
declarations.title: genAsciiChar

declarations.comments: Generates a character in the ASCII character set.
declarations.title: genAsciiChar'

declarations.comments: Generates a character that is a numeric digit.
declarations.title: genDigitChar

declarations.comments: Generates a character from the basic latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlpha

declarations.comments: Generates a lowercase character from the basic latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlphaLowercase

declarations.comments: Generates an uppercase character from the basic latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlphaUppercase

declarations.comments:
CodePoint is an Int bounded between 0 and 0x10FFFF, corresponding to
Unicode code points.
declarations.title: CodePoint

declarations.comments:
Returns a record with the first code point and the remaining code points
of the string. Returns Nothing if the string is empty. Operates in
constant space and time.

```purescript
>>> uncons "𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just { head: CodePoint 0x1D400, tail: "𝐀 c 𝐀" }
>>> uncons ""
Nothing
```
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments:
Creates an array of code points from a string. Operates in space and time
linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> codePointArray = toCodePointArray "b 𝐀𝐀"
>>> codePointArray
[CodePoint 0x62, CodePoint 0x20, CodePoint 0x1D400, CodePoint 0x1D400]
>>> map singleton codePointArray
["b", " ", "𝐀", "𝐀"]
```
declarations.title: toCodePointArray

declarations.comments:
Returns a string containing the leading sequence of code points which all
match the given predicate from the string. Operates in constant space and
in time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> takeWhile (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
"𝐀𝐀"
```
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments:
Returns a string containing the given number of code points from the
beginning of the given string. If the string does not have that many code
points, returns the empty string. Operates in constant space and in time
linear to the given number.

```purescript
>>> take 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
"b 𝐀"
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> take 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
"b �"
```
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
If the string ends with the given suffix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a `Just` value. Otherwise, return
`Nothing`.

```purescript
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc.exe" == Just "psc"
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripSuffix

declarations.comments:
If the string starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a Just value. Otherwise, return Nothing.

```purescript
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "http://purescript.org" == Just "//purescript.org"
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "https://purescript.org" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments:
Splits a string into two substrings, where `before` contains the code
points up to (but not including) the given index, and `after` contains the
rest of the string, from that index on.

```purescript
>>> splitAt 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just { before: "b 𝐀", after: "𝐀 c 𝐀" }
```

Thus the length of `(splitAt i s).before` will equal either `i` or
`length s`, if that is shorter. (Or if `i` is negative the length will be
0.)

In code:
```purescript
length (splitAt i s).before == min (max i 0) (length s)
(splitAt i s).before <> (splitAt i s).after == s
splitAt i s == {before: take i s, after: drop i s}
```
declarations.title: splitAt

declarations.comments:
Creates a string containing just the given code point. Operates in
constant space and time.

```purescript
>>> map singleton (codePointFromInt 0x1D400)
Just "𝐀"
```
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points in the string. Operates in constant
space and in time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> length "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
8
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> length "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
11
```
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Pattern matches following the given index will be
ignored. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> lastIndexOf' (Pattern "𝐀") 5 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 3
>>> lastIndexOf' (Pattern "o") 5 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the last match of the given
pattern in the string. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> lastIndexOf (Pattern "𝐀") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 7
>>> lastIndexOf (Pattern "o") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Pattern matches preceding the given index will be
ignored. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> indexOf' (Pattern "𝐀") 4 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 7
>>> indexOf' (Pattern "o") 4 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> indexOf (Pattern "𝐀") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 2
>>> indexOf (Pattern "o") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf

declarations.comments:
Creates a string from an array of code points. Operates in space and time
linear to the length of the array.

```purescript
>>> codePointArray = toCodePointArray "c 𝐀"
>>> codePointArray
[CodePoint 0x63, CodePoint 0x20, CodePoint 0x1D400]
>>> fromCodePointArray codePointArray
"c 𝐀"
```
declarations.title: fromCodePointArray

declarations.comments:
Drops the leading sequence of code points which all match the given
predicate from the string. Operates in constant space and in time linear
to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> dropWhile (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
" b c 𝐀"
```
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Drops the given number of code points from the beginning of the string. If
the string does not have that many code points, returns the empty string.
Operates in constant space and in time linear to the given number.

```purescript
>>> drop 5 "𝐀𝐀 b c"
"c"
-- compared to Data.String:
>>> drop 5 "𝐀𝐀 b c"
"b c" -- because "𝐀" occupies 2 code units
```
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points in the leading sequence of code points
which all match the given predicate. Operates in constant space and in
time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> countPrefix (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
2
```
declarations.title: countPrefix

declarations.comments:
Checks whether the pattern appears in the given string.

```purescript
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack with needle" == true
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack" == false
```
declarations.title: contains

declarations.comments:
Creates a CodePoint from a given Char.

```purescript
>>> codePointFromChar 'B'
CodePoint 0x42 -- represents 'B'
```
declarations.title: codePointFromChar

declarations.comments:
Returns the first code point of the string after dropping the given number
of code points from the beginning, if there is such a code point. Operates
in constant space and in time linear to the given index.

```purescript
>>> codePointAt 1 "𝐀𝐀𝐀𝐀"
Just (CodePoint 0x1D400) -- represents "𝐀"
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> charAt 1 "𝐀𝐀𝐀𝐀"
Just '�'
```
declarations.title: codePointAt

declarations.comments:
Removes whitespace from the beginning and end of a string, including
[whitespace characters](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.2)
and [line terminators](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.3).

```purescript
trim "   Hello  \n World\n\t    " == "Hello  \n World"
```
declarations.title: trim

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to uppercase.

```purescript
toUpper "Hello" == "HELLO"
```
declarations.title: toUpper

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to lowercase.

```purescript
toLower "hElLo" == "hello"
```
declarations.title: toLower

declarations.comments:
Returns the substrings of the second string separated along occurences
of the first string.

```purescript
split (Pattern " ") "hello world" == ["hello", "world"]
```
declarations.title: split

declarations.comments:
Replaces all occurences of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replaceAll (Pattern "<=") (Replacement "≤") "a <= b <= c" == "a ≤ b ≤ c"
```
declarations.title: replaceAll

declarations.comments:
Replaces the first occurence of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replace (Pattern "<=") (Replacement "≤") "a <= b <= c" == "a ≤ b <= c"
```
declarations.title: replace

declarations.comments:
Returns `true` if the given string is empty.

```purescript
null "" == true
null "Hi" == false
```
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
Compare two strings in a locale-aware fashion. This is in contrast to
the `Ord` instance on `String` which treats strings as arrays of code
units:

```purescript
"ä" `localeCompare` "b" == LT
"ä" `compare` "b" == GT
```
declarations.title: localeCompare

declarations.comments:
Joins the strings in the array together, inserting the first argument
as separator between them.

```purescript
joinWith ", " ["apple", "banana", "orange"] == "apple, banana, orange"
```
declarations.title: joinWith

declarations.comments: A newtype used in cases to specify a replacement for a pattern.
declarations.title: Replacement

declarations.comments:
A newtype used in cases where there is a string to be matched.

```purescript
pursPattern = Pattern ".purs"
--can be used like this:
contains pursPattern "Test.purs"
   == true
```
declarations.title: Pattern

declarations.comments: A newtype for case insensitive string comparisons and ordering.
declarations.title: CaseInsensitiveString

declarations.comments:
If the string ends with the given suffix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a `Just` value. Otherwise, return
`Nothing`.

```purescript
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc.exe" == Just "psc"
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripSuffix

declarations.comments:
If the string starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a Just value. Otherwise, return Nothing.

```purescript
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "http://purescript.org" == Just "//purescript.org"
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "https://purescript.org" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments:
Checks whether the pattern appears in the given string.

```purescript
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack with needle" == true
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack" == false
```
declarations.title: contains

modules.name: Data.String.CodePoints
modules.comments:
These functions allow PureScript strings to be treated as if they were
sequences of Unicode code points instead of their true underlying
implementation (sequences of UTF-16 code units). For nearly all uses of
strings, these functions should be preferred over the ones in
`Data.String.CodeUnits`.

declarations.comments:
CodePoint is an Int bounded between 0 and 0x10FFFF, corresponding to
Unicode code points.
declarations.title: CodePoint

declarations.comments:
Creates a CodePoint from a given Char.

```purescript
>>> codePointFromChar 'B'
CodePoint 0x42 -- represents 'B'
```
declarations.title: codePointFromChar

declarations.comments:
Creates a string containing just the given code point. Operates in
constant space and time.

```purescript
>>> map singleton (codePointFromInt 0x1D400)
Just "𝐀"
```
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments:
Creates a string from an array of code points. Operates in space and time
linear to the length of the array.

```purescript
>>> codePointArray = toCodePointArray "c 𝐀"
>>> codePointArray
[CodePoint 0x63, CodePoint 0x20, CodePoint 0x1D400]
>>> fromCodePointArray codePointArray
"c 𝐀"
```
declarations.title: fromCodePointArray

declarations.comments:
Creates an array of code points from a string. Operates in space and time
linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> codePointArray = toCodePointArray "b 𝐀𝐀"
>>> codePointArray
[CodePoint 0x62, CodePoint 0x20, CodePoint 0x1D400, CodePoint 0x1D400]
>>> map singleton codePointArray
["b", " ", "𝐀", "𝐀"]
```
declarations.title: toCodePointArray

declarations.comments:
Returns the first code point of the string after dropping the given number
of code points from the beginning, if there is such a code point. Operates
in constant space and in time linear to the given index.

```purescript
>>> codePointAt 1 "𝐀𝐀𝐀𝐀"
Just (CodePoint 0x1D400) -- represents "𝐀"
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> charAt 1 "𝐀𝐀𝐀𝐀"
Just '�'
```
declarations.title: codePointAt

declarations.comments:
Returns a record with the first code point and the remaining code points
of the string. Returns Nothing if the string is empty. Operates in
constant space and time.

```purescript
>>> uncons "𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just { head: CodePoint 0x1D400, tail: "𝐀 c 𝐀" }
>>> uncons ""
Nothing
```
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points in the string. Operates in constant
space and in time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> length "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
8
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> length "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
11
```
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points in the leading sequence of code points
which all match the given predicate. Operates in constant space and in
time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> countPrefix (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
2
```
declarations.title: countPrefix

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> indexOf (Pattern "𝐀") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 2
>>> indexOf (Pattern "o") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Pattern matches preceding the given index will be
ignored. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> indexOf' (Pattern "𝐀") 4 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 7
>>> indexOf' (Pattern "o") 4 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the last match of the given
pattern in the string. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> lastIndexOf (Pattern "𝐀") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 7
>>> lastIndexOf (Pattern "o") "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of code points preceding the first match of the given
pattern in the string. Pattern matches following the given index will be
ignored. Returns Nothing when no matches are found.

```purescript
>>> lastIndexOf' (Pattern "𝐀") 5 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just 3
>>> lastIndexOf' (Pattern "o") 5 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns a string containing the given number of code points from the
beginning of the given string. If the string does not have that many code
points, returns the empty string. Operates in constant space and in time
linear to the given number.

```purescript
>>> take 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
"b 𝐀"
-- compare to Data.String:
>>> take 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
"b �"
```
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Returns a string containing the leading sequence of code points which all
match the given predicate from the string. Operates in constant space and
in time linear to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> takeWhile (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
"𝐀𝐀"
```
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments:
Drops the given number of code points from the beginning of the string. If
the string does not have that many code points, returns the empty string.
Operates in constant space and in time linear to the given number.

```purescript
>>> drop 5 "𝐀𝐀 b c"
"c"
-- compared to Data.String:
>>> drop 5 "𝐀𝐀 b c"
"b c" -- because "𝐀" occupies 2 code units
```
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Drops the leading sequence of code points which all match the given
predicate from the string. Operates in constant space and in time linear
to the length of the string.

```purescript
>>> dropWhile (\c -> codePointToInt c == 0x1D400) "𝐀𝐀 b c 𝐀"
" b c 𝐀"
```
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Splits a string into two substrings, where `before` contains the code
points up to (but not including) the given index, and `after` contains the
rest of the string, from that index on.

```purescript
>>> splitAt 3 "b 𝐀𝐀 c 𝐀"
Just { before: "b 𝐀", after: "𝐀 c 𝐀" }
```

Thus the length of `(splitAt i s).before` will equal either `i` or
`length s`, if that is shorter. (Or if `i` is negative the length will be
0.)

In code:
```purescript
length (splitAt i s).before == min (max i 0) (length s)
(splitAt i s).before <> (splitAt i s).after == s
splitAt i s == {before: take i s, after: drop i s}
```
declarations.title: splitAt

declarations.comments:
If the string starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a Just value. Otherwise, return Nothing.

```purescript
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "http://purescript.org" == Just "//purescript.org"
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") "https://purescript.org" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments:
If the string ends with the given suffix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it, as a `Just` value. Otherwise, return
`Nothing`.

```purescript
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc.exe" == Just "psc"
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") "psc" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripSuffix

declarations.comments:
Checks whether the pattern appears in the given string.

```purescript
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack with needle" == true
contains (Pattern "needle") "haystack" == false
```
declarations.title: contains

declarations.comments:
Returns a string of length `1` containing the given character.

```purescript
singleton 'l' == "l"
```
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments:
Converts an array of characters into a string.

```purescript
fromCharArray ['H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o'] == "Hello"
```
declarations.title: fromCharArray

declarations.comments:
Converts the string into an array of characters.

```purescript
toCharArray "Hello☺\n" == ['H','e','l','l','o','☺','\n']
```
declarations.title: toCharArray

declarations.comments:
Returns the character at the given index, if the index is within bounds.

```purescript
charAt 2 "Hello" == Just 'l'
charAt 10 "Hello" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: charAt

declarations.comments:
Converts the string to a character, if the length of the string is
exactly `1`.

```purescript
toChar "l" == Just 'l'
toChar "Hi" == Nothing -- since length is not 1
```
declarations.title: toChar

declarations.comments:
Returns the first character and the rest of the string,
if the string is not empty.

```purescript
uncons "" == Nothing
uncons "Hello World" == Just { head: 'H', tail: "ello World" }
```
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of characters the string is composed of.

```purescript
length "Hello World" == 11
```
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of contiguous characters at the beginning
of the string for which the predicate holds.

```purescript
countPrefix (_ /= ' ') "Hello World" == 5 -- since length "Hello" == 5
```
declarations.title: countPrefix

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the first occurrence of the pattern in the
given string. Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
indexOf (Pattern "c") "abcdc" == Just 2
indexOf (Pattern "c") "aaa" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the first occurrence of the pattern in the
given string, starting at the specified index. Returns `Nothing` if there is
no match.

```purescript
indexOf' (Pattern "a") 2 "ababa" == Just 2
indexOf' (Pattern "a") 3 "ababa" == Just 4
```
declarations.title: indexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the last occurrence of the pattern in the
given string. Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
lastIndexOf (Pattern "c") "abcdc" == Just 4
lastIndexOf (Pattern "c") "aaa" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the last occurrence of the pattern in the
given string, starting at the specified index
and searching backwards towards the beginning of the string.
Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 1 "ababa" == Just 0
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 3 "ababa" == Just 2
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 4 "ababa" == Just 4
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the first `n` characters of the string.

```purescript
take 5 "Hello World" == "Hello"
```
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Returns the last `n` characters of the string.

```purescript
takeRight 5 "Hello World" == "World"
```
declarations.title: takeRight

declarations.comments:
Returns the longest prefix (possibly empty) of characters that satisfy
the predicate.

```purescript
takeWhile (_ /= ':') "http://purescript.org" == "http"
```
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments:
Returns the string without the first `n` characters.

```purescript
drop 6 "Hello World" == "World"
```
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Returns the string without the last `n` characters.

```purescript
dropRight 6 "Hello World" == "Hello"
```
declarations.title: dropRight

declarations.comments:
Returns the suffix remaining after `takeWhile`.

```purescript
dropWhile (_ /= '.') "Test.purs" == ".purs"
```
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Returns the substring at indices `[begin, end)`.
If either index is negative, it is normalised to `length s - index`,
where `s` is the input string. `Nothing` is returned if either
index is out of bounds or if `begin > end` after normalisation.

```purescript
slice 0 0   "purescript" == Just ""
slice 0 1   "purescript" == Just "p"
slice 3 6   "purescript" == Just "esc"
slice (-4) (-1) "purescript" == Just "rip"
slice (-4) 3  "purescript" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: slice

declarations.comments:
Splits a string into two substrings, where `before` contains the
characters up to (but not including) the given index, and `after` contains
the rest of the string, from that index on.

```purescript
splitAt 2 "Hello World" == { before: "He", after: "llo World"}
splitAt 10 "Hi" == { before: "Hi", after: ""}
```

Thus the length of `(splitAt i s).before` will equal either `i` or
`length s`, if that is shorter. (Or if `i` is negative the length will be
0.)

In code:
```purescript
length (splitAt i s).before == min (max i 0) (length s)
(splitAt i s).before <> (splitAt i s).after == s
splitAt i s == {before: take i s, after: drop i s}
```
declarations.title: splitAt

declarations.comments:
Returns `true` if the given string is empty.

```purescript
null "" == true
null "Hi" == false
```
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
Compare two strings in a locale-aware fashion. This is in contrast to
the `Ord` instance on `String` which treats strings as arrays of code
units:

```purescript
"ä" `localeCompare` "b" == LT
"ä" `compare` "b" == GT
```
declarations.title: localeCompare

declarations.comments:
Replaces the first occurence of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replace (Pattern "<=") (Replacement "≤") "a <= b <= c" == "a ≤ b <= c"
```
declarations.title: replace

declarations.comments:
Replaces all occurences of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replaceAll (Pattern "<=") (Replacement "≤") "a <= b <= c" == "a ≤ b ≤ c"
```
declarations.title: replaceAll

declarations.comments:
Returns the substrings of the second string separated along occurences
of the first string.

```purescript
split (Pattern " ") "hello world" == ["hello", "world"]
```
declarations.title: split

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to lowercase.

```purescript
toLower "hElLo" == "hello"
```
declarations.title: toLower

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to uppercase.

```purescript
toUpper "Hello" == "HELLO"
```
declarations.title: toUpper

declarations.comments:
Removes whitespace from the beginning and end of a string, including
[whitespace characters](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.2)
and [line terminators](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.3).

```purescript
trim "   Hello  \n World\n\t    " == "Hello  \n World"
```
declarations.title: trim

declarations.comments:
Joins the strings in the array together, inserting the first argument
as separator between them.

```purescript
joinWith ", " ["apple", "banana", "orange"] == "apple, banana, orange"
```
declarations.title: joinWith

declarations.comments: Generates a string using the specified character generator.
declarations.title: genString

declarations.comments:
Generates a string using characters from the Unicode basic multilingual
plain.
declarations.title: genUnicodeString

declarations.comments: Generates a string using the ASCII character set, excluding control codes.
declarations.title: genAsciiString

declarations.comments: Generates a string using the ASCII character set.
declarations.title: genAsciiString'

declarations.comments: Generates a string made up of numeric digits.
declarations.title: genDigitString

declarations.comments: Generates a string using characters from the basic Latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlphaString

declarations.comments: Generates a string using lowercase characters from the basic Latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlphaLowercaseString

declarations.comments: Generates a string using uppercase characters from the basic Latin alphabet.
declarations.title: genAlphaUppercaseString

declarations.comments: A string that is known not to be empty.
declarations.title: NonEmptyString

declarations.comments: A newtype used in cases to specify a non-empty replacement for a pattern.
declarations.title: NonEmptyReplacement

contents.contents: Cannot create an NonEmptyString from an empty Symbol

declarations.comments:
A helper class for defining non-empty string values at compile time.

``` purescript
something :: NonEmptyString
something = nes (SProxy :: SProxy "something")
```
declarations.title: MakeNonEmpty

declarations.comments: A partial version of `fromString`.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments:
Removes whitespace from the beginning and end of a string, including
[whitespace characters](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.2)
and [line terminators](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.3).
If the string is entirely made up of whitespace the result will be Nothing.

```purescript
trim (NonEmptyString "   Hello  \n World\n\t    ") == Just (NonEmptyString "Hello  \n World")
trim (NonEmptyString "   \n") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: trim

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to uppercase.

```purescript
toUpper (NonEmptyString "Hello") == NonEmptyString "HELLO"
```
declarations.title: toUpper

declarations.comments: Converts a `NonEmptyString` back into a standard `String`.
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to lowercase.

```purescript
toLower (NonEmptyString "hElLo") == NonEmptyString "hello"
```
declarations.title: toLower

declarations.comments:
If the string ends with the given suffix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it. If the suffix does not match or there is no
remainder, the result will be `Nothing`.

```purescript
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") (NonEmptyString "purs.exe") == Just (NonEmptyString "purs")
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") (NonEmptyString "purs") == Nothing
stripSuffix (Pattern "Hello!") (NonEmptyString "Hello!") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripSuffix

declarations.comments:
If the string starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it. If the prefix does not match or there is no
remainder, the result will be `Nothing`.

```purescript
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") (NonEmptyString "http://purescript.org") == Just (NonEmptyString "//purescript.org")
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") (NonEmptyString "https://purescript.org") == Nothing
stripPrefix (Pattern "Hello!") (NonEmptyString "Hello!") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments:
Replaces all occurences of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replaceAll (Pattern "<=") (NonEmptyReplacement "≤") (NonEmptyString "a <= b <= c") == NonEmptyString "a ≤ b ≤ c"
```
declarations.title: replaceAll

declarations.comments:
Replaces the first occurence of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replace (Pattern "<=") (NonEmptyReplacement "≤") (NonEmptyString "a <= b <= c") == NonEmptyString "a ≤ b <= c"
```
declarations.title: replace

declarations.comments:
Prepends a string to this non-empty string. Since one of the strings is
non-empty we know the result will be too.

```purescript
prependString "be" (NonEmptyString "fore") == NonEmptyString "before"
prependString "" (NonEmptyString "fore") == NonEmptyString "fore"
```
declarations.title: prependString

declarations.comments:
Compare two strings in a locale-aware fashion. This is in contrast to
the `Ord` instance on `String` which treats strings as arrays of code
units:

```purescript
NonEmptyString "ä" `localeCompare` NonEmptyString "b" == LT
NonEmptyString "ä" `compare` NonEmptyString "b" == GT
```
declarations.title: localeCompare

declarations.comments:
Joins possibly empty strings in a non-empty container together as a new
non-empty string, inserting a non-empty string as a separator between them.
The result is guaranteed to be non-empty.

```purescript
-- array syntax is used for demonstration here, it would need to be a real `Foldable1`
joinWith1 (NonEmptyString ", ") ["apple", "banana"] == NonEmptyString "apple, banana"
joinWith1 (NonEmptyString "/") ["a", "b", "", "c", ""] == NonEmptyString "a/b//c/"
```
declarations.title: joinWith1

declarations.comments:
Joins the strings in a container together as a new string, inserting the
first argument as separator between them. The result is not guaranteed to
be non-empty.

```purescript
joinWith ", " [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == "apple, banana"
joinWith ", " [] == ""
```
declarations.title: joinWith

declarations.comments:
Joins non-empty strings in a non-empty container together as a new
non-empty string, inserting a possibly empty string as separator between
them. The result is guaranteed to be non-empty.

```purescript
-- array syntax is used for demonstration here, it would need to be a real `Foldable1`
join1With ", " [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == NonEmptyString "apple, banana"
join1With "" [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == NonEmptyString "applebanana"
```
declarations.title: join1With

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a `String`, returning `Nothing` if the
input is empty.

```purescript
fromString "" = Nothing
fromString "hello" = Just (NES.unsafeFromString "hello")
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments:
Checks whether the pattern appears in the given string.

```purescript
contains (Pattern "needle") (NonEmptyString "haystack with needle") == true
contains (Pattern "needle") (NonEmptyString "haystack") == false
```
declarations.title: contains

declarations.comments:
Appends a string to this non-empty string. Since one of the strings is
non-empty we know the result will be too.

```purescript
appendString (NonEmptyString "Hello") " world" == NonEmptyString "Hello world"
appendString (NonEmptyString "Hello") "" == NonEmptyString "Hello"
```
declarations.title: appendString

declarations.comments:
A newtype used in cases where there is a string to be matched.

```purescript
pursPattern = Pattern ".purs"
--can be used like this:
contains pursPattern "Test.purs"
   == true
```
declarations.title: Pattern

declarations.comments: A newtype for case insensitive string comparisons and ordering.
declarations.title: CaseInsensitiveNonEmptyString

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a character array `String`, returning
`Nothing` if the input is empty.

```purescript
fromCharArray [] = Nothing
fromCharArray ['a', 'b', 'c'] = Just (NonEmptyString "abc")
```
declarations.title: fromCharArray

declarations.comments: Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a character.
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a string by prepending a character.

```purescript
cons 'a' "bc" = NonEmptyString "abc"
cons 'a' "" = NonEmptyString "a"
```
declarations.title: cons

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a string by appending a character.

```purescript
snoc 'c' "ab" = NonEmptyString "abc"
snoc 'a' "" = NonEmptyString "a"
```
declarations.title: snoc

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a `Foldable1` container carrying
characters.
declarations.title: fromFoldable1

declarations.comments:
Converts the `NonEmptyString` into an array of characters.

```purescript
toCharArray (NonEmptyString "Hello☺\n") == ['H','e','l','l','o','☺','\n']
```
declarations.title: toCharArray

declarations.comments: Converts the `NonEmptyString` into a non-empty array of characters.
declarations.title: toNonEmptyCharArray

declarations.comments:
Returns the character at the given index, if the index is within bounds.

```purescript
charAt 2 (NonEmptyString "Hello") == Just 'l'
charAt 10 (NonEmptyString "Hello") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: charAt

declarations.comments:
Converts the `NonEmptyString` to a character, if the length of the string
is exactly `1`.

```purescript
toChar "H" == Just 'H'
toChar "Hi" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: toChar

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the first occurrence of the pattern in the
given string. Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
indexOf (Pattern "c") (NonEmptyString "abcdc") == Just 2
indexOf (Pattern "c") (NonEmptyString "aaa") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: indexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the first occurrence of the pattern in the
given string, starting at the specified index. Returns `Nothing` if there is
no match.

```purescript
indexOf' (Pattern "a") 2 (NonEmptyString "ababa") == Just 2
indexOf' (Pattern "a") 3 (NonEmptyString "ababa") == Just 4
```
declarations.title: indexOf'

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the last occurrence of the pattern in the
given string. Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
lastIndexOf (Pattern "c") (NonEmptyString "abcdc") == Just 4
lastIndexOf (Pattern "c") (NonEmptyString "aaa") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf

declarations.comments:
Returns the index of the last occurrence of the pattern in the
given string, starting at the specified index
and searching backwards towards the beginning of the string.
Returns `Nothing` if there is no match.

```purescript
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 1 (NonEmptyString "ababa") == Just 0
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 3 (NonEmptyString "ababa") == Just 2
lastIndexOf' (Pattern "a") 4 (NonEmptyString "ababa") == Just 4
```
declarations.title: lastIndexOf'
uncons

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of characters the string is composed of.

```purescript
length (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == 11
```
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Returns the first `n` characters of the string. Returns `Nothing` if `n` is
less than 1.

```purescript
take 5 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Just (NonEmptyString "Hello")
take 0 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Returns the last `n` characters of the string. Returns `Nothing` if `n` is
less than 1.

```purescript
take 5 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Just (NonEmptyString "World")
take 0 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: takeRight

declarations.comments:
Returns the longest prefix of characters that satisfy the predicate.
`Nothing` is returned if there is no matching prefix.

```purescript
takeWhile (_ /= ':') (NonEmptyString "http://purescript.org") == Just (NonEmptyString "http")
takeWhile (_ == 'a') (NonEmptyString "xyz") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments:
Returns the string without the first `n` characters. Returns `Nothing` if
more characters are dropped than the string is long.

```purescript
drop 6 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Just (NonEmptyString "World")
drop 20 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Returns the string without the last `n` characters. Returns `Nothing` if
more characters are dropped than the string is long.

```purescript
dropRight 6 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Just (NonEmptyString "Hello")
dropRight 20 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: dropRight

declarations.comments:
Returns the suffix remaining after `takeWhile`.

```purescript
dropWhile (_ /= '.') (NonEmptyString "Test.purs") == Just (NonEmptyString ".purs")
```
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of contiguous characters at the beginning of the string
for which the predicate holds.

```purescript
countPrefix (_ /= 'o') (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == 4
```
declarations.title: countPrefix

declarations.comments:
Returns the substrings of a split at the given index, if the index is
within bounds.

```purescript
splitAt 2 (NonEmptyString "Hello World") == Just { before: Just (NonEmptyString "He"), after: Just (NonEmptyString "llo World") }
splitAt 10 (NonEmptyString "Hi") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: splitAt

declarations.comments: A string that is known not to be empty.
declarations.title: NonEmptyString

contents.contents: Cannot create an NonEmptyString from an empty Symbol

declarations.comments:
A helper class for defining non-empty string values at compile time.

``` purescript
something :: NonEmptyString
something = nes (SProxy :: SProxy "something")
```
declarations.title: MakeNonEmpty

declarations.comments: A newtype used in cases to specify a non-empty replacement for a pattern.
declarations.title: NonEmptyReplacement

declarations.comments:
Creates a `NonEmptyString` from a `String`, returning `Nothing` if the
input is empty.

```purescript
fromString "" = Nothing
fromString "hello" = Just (NES.unsafeFromString "hello")
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments: A partial version of `fromString`.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments: Converts a `NonEmptyString` back into a standard `String`.
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Appends a string to this non-empty string. Since one of the strings is
non-empty we know the result will be too.

```purescript
appendString (NonEmptyString "Hello") " world" == NonEmptyString "Hello world"
appendString (NonEmptyString "Hello") "" == NonEmptyString "Hello"
```
declarations.title: appendString

declarations.comments:
Prepends a string to this non-empty string. Since one of the strings is
non-empty we know the result will be too.

```purescript
prependString "be" (NonEmptyString "fore") == NonEmptyString "before"
prependString "" (NonEmptyString "fore") == NonEmptyString "fore"
```
declarations.title: prependString

declarations.comments:
If the string starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it. If the prefix does not match or there is no
remainder, the result will be `Nothing`.

```purescript
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") (NonEmptyString "http://purescript.org") == Just (NonEmptyString "//purescript.org")
stripPrefix (Pattern "http:") (NonEmptyString "https://purescript.org") == Nothing
stripPrefix (Pattern "Hello!") (NonEmptyString "Hello!") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments:
If the string ends with the given suffix, return the portion of the
string left after removing it. If the suffix does not match or there is no
remainder, the result will be `Nothing`.

```purescript
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") (NonEmptyString "purs.exe") == Just (NonEmptyString "purs")
stripSuffix (Pattern ".exe") (NonEmptyString "purs") == Nothing
stripSuffix (Pattern "Hello!") (NonEmptyString "Hello!") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: stripSuffix

declarations.comments:
Checks whether the pattern appears in the given string.

```purescript
contains (Pattern "needle") (NonEmptyString "haystack with needle") == true
contains (Pattern "needle") (NonEmptyString "haystack") == false
```
declarations.title: contains

declarations.comments:
Compare two strings in a locale-aware fashion. This is in contrast to
the `Ord` instance on `String` which treats strings as arrays of code
units:

```purescript
NonEmptyString "ä" `localeCompare` NonEmptyString "b" == LT
NonEmptyString "ä" `compare` NonEmptyString "b" == GT
```
declarations.title: localeCompare

declarations.comments:
Replaces the first occurence of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replace (Pattern "<=") (NonEmptyReplacement "≤") (NonEmptyString "a <= b <= c") == NonEmptyString "a ≤ b <= c"
```
declarations.title: replace

declarations.comments:
Replaces all occurences of the pattern with the replacement string.

```purescript
replaceAll (Pattern "<=") (NonEmptyReplacement "≤") (NonEmptyString "a <= b <= c") == NonEmptyString "a ≤ b ≤ c"
```
declarations.title: replaceAll

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to lowercase.

```purescript
toLower (NonEmptyString "hElLo") == NonEmptyString "hello"
```
declarations.title: toLower

declarations.comments:
Returns the argument converted to uppercase.

```purescript
toUpper (NonEmptyString "Hello") == NonEmptyString "HELLO"
```
declarations.title: toUpper

declarations.comments:
Removes whitespace from the beginning and end of a string, including
[whitespace characters](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.2)
and [line terminators](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.3).
If the string is entirely made up of whitespace the result will be Nothing.

```purescript
trim (NonEmptyString "   Hello  \n World\n\t    ") == Just (NonEmptyString "Hello  \n World")
trim (NonEmptyString "   \n") == Nothing
```
declarations.title: trim

declarations.comments:
Joins the strings in a container together as a new string, inserting the
first argument as separator between them. The result is not guaranteed to
be non-empty.

```purescript
joinWith ", " [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == "apple, banana"
joinWith ", " [] == ""
```
declarations.title: joinWith

declarations.comments:
Joins non-empty strings in a non-empty container together as a new
non-empty string, inserting a possibly empty string as separator between
them. The result is guaranteed to be non-empty.

```purescript
-- array syntax is used for demonstration here, it would need to be a real `Foldable1`
join1With ", " [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == NonEmptyString "apple, banana"
join1With "" [NonEmptyString "apple", NonEmptyString "banana"] == NonEmptyString "applebanana"
```
declarations.title: join1With

declarations.comments:
Joins possibly empty strings in a non-empty container together as a new
non-empty string, inserting a non-empty string as a separator between them.
The result is guaranteed to be non-empty.

```purescript
-- array syntax is used for demonstration here, it would need to be a real `Foldable1`
joinWith1 (NonEmptyString ", ") ["apple", "banana"] == NonEmptyString "apple, banana"
joinWith1 (NonEmptyString "/") ["a", "b", "", "c", ""] == NonEmptyString "a/b//c/"
```
declarations.title: joinWith1

declarations.comments:
A newtype used in cases where there is a string to be matched.

```purescript
pursPattern = Pattern ".purs"
--can be used like this:
contains pursPattern "Test.purs"
   == true
```
declarations.title: Pattern

declarations.comments: A newtype used in cases to specify a replacement for a pattern.
declarations.title: Replacement

modules.name: Data.String.Regex
modules.comments:
Wraps Javascript's `RegExp` object that enables matching strings with
patternes defined by regular expressions.
For details of the underlying implementation, see [RegExp Reference at MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/RegExp).

declarations.comments: Wraps Javascript `RegExp` objects.
declarations.title: Regex

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `Regex` from a pattern string and flags. Fails with
`Left error` if the pattern contains a syntax error.
declarations.title: regex

declarations.comments: Returns the pattern string used to construct the given `Regex`.
declarations.title: source

declarations.comments: Returns the `RegexFlags` used to construct the given `Regex`.
declarations.title: flags

declarations.comments: Returns the string representation of the given `RegexFlags`.
declarations.title: renderFlags

declarations.comments: Parses the string representation of `RegexFlags`.
declarations.title: parseFlags

declarations.comments:
Returns `true` if the `Regex` matches the string. In contrast to
`RegExp.prototype.test()` in JavaScript, `test` does not affect
the `lastIndex` property of the Regex.
declarations.title: test

declarations.comments:
Matches the string against the `Regex` and returns an array of matches
if there were any. Each match has type `Maybe String`, where `Nothing`
represents an unmatched optional capturing group.
See [reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/match).
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Replaces occurences of the `Regex` with the first string. The replacement
string can include special replacement patterns escaped with `"$"`.
See [reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/replace).
declarations.title: replace

declarations.comments:
Transforms occurences of the `Regex` using a function of the matched
substring and a list of submatch strings.
See the [reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/replace#Specifying_a_function_as_a_parameter).
declarations.title: replace'

declarations.comments:
Returns `Just` the index of the first match of the `Regex` in the string,
or `Nothing` if there is no match.
declarations.title: search

declarations.comments: Split the string into an array of substrings along occurences of the `Regex`.
declarations.title: split

declarations.comments: Flags that control matching.
declarations.title: RegexFlags

declarations.comments: All flags set to false.
declarations.title: noFlags

declarations.comments: Only global flag set to true
declarations.title: global

declarations.comments: Only ignoreCase flag set to true
declarations.title: ignoreCase

declarations.comments: Only multiline flag set to true
declarations.title: multiline

declarations.comments: Only sticky flag set to true
declarations.title: sticky

declarations.comments: Only unicode flag set to true
declarations.title: unicode

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `Regex` from a pattern string and flags. Fails with
an exception if the pattern contains a syntax error.
declarations.title: unsafeRegex

declarations.comments:
Converts a string of length `1` to a character.

**Unsafe:** throws runtime exception if length is not `1`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments:
Returns the character at the given index.

**Unsafe:** throws runtime exception if the index is out of bounds.
declarations.title: charAt
